name: Emerald Green
description:
Custer Feldspar used.
Too much copper, will try 5% next time.
Not food safe.
Do not luster
Does not craze on Standard cone 6 porcelain 365
very glossy and rich
do not glaze interiors of pots because too much glaze melting causes blisters but the exterior is good.

This is from HP Bloomer potash gloss

name: Jake's Best
description:
In search of a glaze similar to the popular Ashley's Best, I developed this glaze, which doesn't use lithium or lithium feldspar. This glaze is a magnesium crystalline matte. Where thick, it is a bight phase separated cobalt gloss. Where thinner, it is a deep violet matte glaze. 

Added 95% water. 

This glaze is stable with a 4 second dip. 

Looking at flux ratios, this *should* be a durable glaze safe for food use, but testing is critical to determine this without a shadow of a doubt.

name: Lynette's Opal
description: From page 125 of John Britt's *The Complete Guide to Mid-Range Glazes*.  I mainly use this glaze to layer over the top of others, particularly zinc-rich cobalt purple glazes.

name: Alabama Rain
description: Alabama Rain  with added Rutile fired on Standard #266 clay.

name: Silver Moon Crater Glaze
description:
White glaze with craters and silvery colour on the crater edges
Not for food surfaces (due to glaze open pores).
Easy glaze to apply and use.
No running but be careful of the craters around edges as they can be sharp.
The top and interior of the first picture (glazed bowl) is simply the same glaze with no silicon carbide (SiC), which produces a nice white. This is the white recipe: https://glazy.org/recipes/52127

name: Peacock
description: When you try a SiC reduced chun. Very thick glazing. Very nicely drippy, fire with shelf protection. Used 1000 mesh SiC.

name: Sue White Lichen #4
description:
## Sue's Notes
Needs to be thick to crawl, but not so thick that it falls off.

## Free glaze resources:
https://suemcleodceramics.com/blog - articles about glazes, clay and studio operations
[Understanding Glazes with Sue - Facebook group](https://www.facebook.com/groups/UnderstandingGlazes) - All clay, glaze and kiln questions welcome.
## Online glaze classes with Sue:
Online classes and workshops about glaze mixing, testing, materials, chemistry, and using the glaze calculation tools of Glazy

name: Dusk pink
description: A reworking of Val's turquoise for the gerstley borateless.

name: Mermaid Tail
description:
Soft, satin matte glaze. The titanium is what is giving this glaze its speckled crystallization. 

By definition, all matte glazes are crystalline glazes. To cause this to seed more crystals with more variegation, the titanium acts as a nucleation point for them. A thicker application causes smaller crystals whereas a thinner coat causes more crystals with greater variation in size. Thinner allows for more of the clay body to show through. This glaze does show texture. Thinner= better crystalliz

materials.name: Feldespato Potásico Standard Piedra Grande/Dp , hasta 2023

name: Semi-matte OFF WHITE
description:
This is a semi matte off-white recipe with Dolomite as Flux and Tin (8%) as opacifier.
It should give good coverage also with only 5-6% Tin.

It has been tested with oxides (on top of 8% Tin) and gave good results with:
- Nickel Carbonate 1,3% (more white/beige)
- Manganese dioxide 1% (light brown)
- Cobalt oxide 0,3% (Light blue)
- Copper Carbonate 2% (Light green)


The water content is 120%.

If applied too thick it can cause pinholes, 2-3 sec dipping should be enough.

Normal firing schedule

name: Tickled Pink (Gabriel Kline)
description: This is a very stable opaque white/pink glaze---if you're not getting the pink you want, add a TINY (a few granules) bit more chromium oxide to react with the tin in the firing.  This dips well but does not brush well---perhaps a gum solution might fix that.

name: Marcia's Matte
description: Very smooth colorless Satin matte that works well over underglaze. Corrected crazing over porcelain. Progressively increase the silica to adjust the matte level / gloss level. This composition has been tested and will go full gloss with higher silica levels. This composition has a tiny bit more boron than necessary to ensure melt over most heavy under-glazed areas. Suggest apply smooth uniform thin layers.

name: OldForge Floating Pink (FirstFive)
description:
Chrome Tin Pink, based loosely on a Floating Blue recipe

The titanium dioxide helps develop the colour without needing as much tin, making it much cheaper and adding more variegation to the glaze flows.

name: Cone 6 Pink
description: A cone 6 glossy pink based on a tweak of Tony Hansen's 20X5. Cloudier where thick. 0.02 chrome is not a mistake - it is 1/10 of the usual, already low, amount of chrome oxide in chrome tin pinks and reds.

name: Dan's Shiny White (no craze?)
description:
A glossy white that I designed to be less likely to craze but haven't extensively tested it. It will depend on the clay used too. 

Test pics all same bowl fired in electric oxidation at a slightly hot cone 6.

name: OldForge FreedomFive Gloss Base
description:
This is one of a selection of straightforward recipes that use the same 5 base ingredients, to give an easy starting point to buying ingredients and mixing glazes: https://www.oldforgecreations.co.uk/blog/freedomfive-glazes-getting-started-with-mixing-glazes

This is a simple glossy base. It shouldn't craze on most clay bodies, and shouldn't run much at all within the firing range.

It works well as a contrasting cover glaze with the addition of 10% zircon

name: Faux Celadon Zn SiC Biax B4
description:
One of the best results from a biaxial testing the effect of Silicon Carbide and Zinc Oxide on oxidation celadons.

This is not a "fake" celadon, the color comes from the reduction of iron.

Ironic that the original inspiration for this glaze is from [Faux Celadon 2 (Minspar sub Kona F-4)](https://glazy.org/recipes/46603) and it's updated variation [Faux Celadon 2 (Minspar version 2)](https://glazy.org/recipes/61480)

See this glazy post for more information: https://glazy.org/posts/129908

name: [272] K3 Roodijzer Mangaan
description: This glaze is developed in the K3 Glaze research project of Jeannine Vrins. The aim is to look for the lowest melting temperature, low amounts of colourants and frits and a low ecological impact. The Kaolin in this glaze is a Polwhite from Imerys and has a low Alumina content and a higher KNa content than other kaolins. If you use another kaolin I suggest to find the right temperature which will be a bit higher than the 1180°C I fired these to a well molten surface. Another way to lower your tem

name: Clear Glossy
description: An excellent base. Easy to apply, responds beautifully to colorants, very stable with no running, transparent and glossy. Smooth, pleasant texture

name: Crackle Pink
description:
Glossy
Dense crackle network with Walkers SES, less crazing with PB 103
Pink

name: Sue's Woo-8
description:
## Sue's Notes
This is one test from a large series of "Woo Yellow" testing that I did.

I added a bunch of Gerstley borate to this one, which threw off the ratio of CaO to SrO which is why it's brown and not yellow.
## Free glaze resources:
https://suemcleodceramics.com/blog - articles about glazes, clay and studio operations
[Understanding Glazes with Sue - Facebook group](https://www.facebook.com/groups/UnderstandingGlazes) - All clay, glaze and kiln questions welcome.
## Online glaze classes

name: Cream Soda Float
description:
5% Dark red stain creates pink, 2% Zircopax can be added when using encapsulated stains. Follow the following firing schedule to a soft cone 6 for best results:
Seg. Ramp. Temp. Hold.
1.         200f     250f   0
2.        400.      1000.  0
3.        180.       1150.   0
4.        300.       1967.  0
5.        200.       2160.  5 min
6.        150.       1900.   30 min

name: Electric Unicorn
description:
7% Dark red stain creates hot pink however less stain can be added for shade variation.  Still testing to resolve bubbling where the glaze pools. The application was also quite thick. 
Follow the following firing schedule for a soft cone 6 for best results:
Seg. Ramp. Temp. Hold.
1.         200f     250f   0
2.        400.      1000.  0
3.        180.       1150.   0
4.        300.       1967.  0
5.        200.       2160.  5 min
6.        150.       1900.   30 min

name: ArtLab Lizard Skin
description:
Alumina matte glaze with some copper.

!Warning! There's a lot of kaolin in this glaze, so use 18% kaolin and 7,7% calcined kaolin. Otherwise with 28% kaolin, the glaze will most likely crawl really bad. 
Calcined kaolin is easy to make, just bisque fire the kaolin and there you go. 

Works well for cone 6-7. Used on buff stoneware clay.
Ingredients are in Dutch: kwarts = silica, krijt = whiting. Colpaert is the Belgian supplier.
Let me know how it works for you!

For more glazes, tips & tricks,

name: Reptar
description:
A glossier semi-matte crystal forming glaze with a nice green hue that evokes something lizardly.

I prefer my glazes with a thicker consistency. Mix thoroughly and only do a 1-2 second dip. 

Without the bentonite, this glaze will hard pan with the best of ‘em.

name: Ve ru estroncio 200820.A2,5 version con fritas en vez de GB y 1% de cobre en vez de 3% original
description:
Teste de color sobre Ve ru estroncio 200820.A2,5
La receta original tenia GB, voy a adaptarla a frita.
Salió mas pastel y tirando a celeste. Donde acumuló (reverso del test) quedó brillante, craquelado, mas verde manzana claro). OJO! Le puse 1% de ox Cu en vez de 3%

name: Kelp, Dawn & Dusk - Tea Dust Variations
description:
This recipe was a miraculous find as it was the first test that was successful using Aardvark Charcoal Clay after testing for 2 years. I have the RIO listed in this recipe because it was the original version I tested (from Temmoku Basic (Line 5) recipe here on Glazy). Subsequent versions with Rutile and Copper Carb came later. 

The three variations I have had success with:
Kelp (+10 Red Iron Oxide) (only the Kelp version uses RIO) 
Dusk (+6 Rutile - pinkish)
Dawn (+6 Rutile/1 Copper Carb - blui

name: Locke's Residue
description:
Featured in Ceramics Monthly (Feb 2026) Techno Files "Bright Colors in Foam".

High-silica foaming glaze resulting in a strong glossy finish which doesn't run much at cone 6.  Use 35% water and 2% Darvan 7 to make a viscous mixture.  Apply thick to get full effect. (Darvan helps reduce cracking while drying, which helps reduce crawling when firing.  Thinning with water leads to cracking and then crawling.)

With silicon carbide only, colors are drab.  With Epsom salt only, colors are bright, but

name: Celeste medio Katz-Burke Matte (adapted to LM)
description:
Adapte a mis materiales. 
 A durable, true matte glaze that is craze resistant on several cone 6 porcelain bodies. 
Craquela em argila farias ocre 50%

name: rumena satin jakob, nižji Al PROU ZA TEST SCENA
description:
dodana silica to combat the crazing. sicer iznici matiranje..

testirano v 4 koncentracijah zeleza in 4 koncentracijah silice dodane...

vsak od lončkov ima 1,2,3,4 % rumenega zelezo oksida
dip
dodan 10% (of dry glaze weight) oz 10g silice v vsak loncek in 10g vode da se nebi po vsakem novem dipu glejz ful zgostil
dip
dodan 10% (of dry glaze weight) oz 10g silice v vsak loncek in 10g vode
.....
4ponovljeno X 4 razlicni Fe =16 test tajlov
najprej mat pokajoči proti vednobol gladkemu ne popokanemu

name: soft Terracota
description:
WARME MATTE TERRACOTAKLEUR MET ZACHTE UITSTRALING
SATIJNMAT TOT GLANZEND AFHANKELIJK VAN LAAGDIKTE EN STOOK

name: Nieuw recept 01 porseleinwit glans
description: wit glanzend, transparant in dunne laag

description: A durable, true matte glaze

description: A true matte glaze

name: LMG
description:
NOTE: This recipe was imported from Triangle Potter's Guild Glaze Recipes published November, 1988

Source: Conrad Weiser

14.0 lithium carbonate
27.2 kingman feldspar
14.8 whiting
12.8 epk
31.2 flint
+ 2 copper carbonate

SemiMatte, Glossy SemiMottled Matte

Be careful and test well on your clay body. It shivers sometimes on some clay bodies.

name: Matte & White
description:
NOTE: This recipe was imported from Triangle Potter's Guild Glaze Recipes published November, 1988

Source: Conrad Weiser

51.6 potash feldspar (custer)
5.6 flint
18.8 whiting
8.6 zinc oxide
15.4 epk

description:
This is one of a selection of straightforward recipes that use the same 5 base ingredients, to give an easy starting point to buying ingredients and mixing glazes: https://www.oldforgecreations.co.uk/blog/freedomfive-glazes-getting-started-with-mixing-glazes

Fairly generic glossy base with the titanium pushing it up into the matte region, which results in the hazy speckles where thicker.

name: Blanc lustré-Argile Atelier
description: See : https://www.digitalfire.com/recipe/g2926b

name: Noir lustré-Argile atelier
description: Stain=Pigment Mason noir (5%) Best Black

name: low expansion pink (5.6)
description: trying to formulate a glaze with emphasis on reducing thermal expansion for my lanthanide experiments, as my regular clear crazed within hours after firing on this clay (georgies trillium). I made this from scratch in glazy using the limit window for guidance. I'll observe it for a few days before the final verdict but it looks very nice. First time using Lithium as an R20 flux, but it didn't seem to have moved a lot, if anything it got a little thicker near the bottom line where I applied it. w

name: Peacock (Copy)
description: When you try a SiC reduced chun. Very thick glazing. Very nicely drippy, fire with shelf protection. Used 1000 mesh SiC.

name: Black Ivory M233864
description:
recalculation with local materials.

Based on Old Forge's version of Heath's Ivory. Same thing, but with colourants to create a (very) deep purple/black. It can be brown at some points, metallic at others. Fun glaze that creates interesting effects on its own and when layered.

name: laogai green E10560
description:
A recalculation of the original, using a frit locally available and cheaper than the Ferro original. From the original notes:
This glaze is an off-shoot of a glaze recommended to me by a few people. here is the original glaze.
https://glazy.org/recipes/67471

as a base glaze its great but it was far too dark green and i really wanted a stronger melt. I took 3% of the oxide out and replaced it to keep some darkness and kept much of the rutile. I got exactly what i thought i would. A nice melty gr

name: Sweet Minty Turquoise A8962
description: Adaptation to available frit.

name: Clear - High boron rework (Copy)
description:
Glossy transparent. Works well over coloured porcelain or underglaze colours
Rework of (Glazy ID 327473) adjusted to reduce fluidity.
Add 8% red stain and 3% zirconium silicate for a red glaze.

description:

name: Purple Matt
description:
Based on glaze recipe 2824 Purple Matt from “Dry Glazes” by Jeremy Jernegan, credited to P. Horsrley, also found here:  https://patrickhorsley.com/glazes/

Reformulated to:

-get rid of the Frit 403 (this Frit has so little boron that it didn’t register in Glazy’s UMF calculations).   
- replace kinsman feldspar with Custer feldspar (I suspect other potassium feldspars will work similarly)
- eliminate the ball clay and the veegum/bentonite (it suspends fine with the EPK).   

It does crack sligh

name: Mamo purple low Al
description: For a line blend into its parent glaze. Really looks like more of a purple fake ash glaze.

name: Alabama Rain (Copy)
description: Alabama Rain on standard 240 clay.

name: Da Penha 2023
description:
NOTE: This recipe was imported from Triangle Potter's Guild Glaze Recipes published November, 1988

Source: Conrad Weiser

41.3 potash feldspar
14.9 whiting
12.0 zinc oxide
4.9 epk
26.9 silica
+ 5.0 titanium dioxide

This is a white basic glaze which will show texture nicely. Two or three dips gives a glossy surface. Is especially attractive over an albany slip underglaze decoration.

With colorant additions you get:
Nickel Oxide 0.5 5% Varying degrees of greenish cream.
Cobalt Ca
